description:
Cricetomys gambianus, commonly known as the Gambian pouched rat, is a species of rodent belonging to the family Nesomyidae. It is native to West and Central Africa, found in countries such as Senegal, Gambia, Guinea-Bissau, Guinea, Sierra Leone, Liberia, Ivory Coast, Ghana, Togo, Benin, Nigeria, Cameroon, Central African Republic, and Democratic Republic of the Congo.

The Gambian pouched rat is a large rodent, with a head-and-body length ranging from 30 to 40 cm and a tail length of 25 to 35 cm. It has a stocky build, large eyes, and prominent external cheek pouches. The fur is coarse and varies in color from grayish-brown to reddish-brown, with a lighter underside. These rats are primarily nocturnal and omnivorous, feeding on a variety of plant materials, insects, and small vertebrates.

Cricetomys gambianus is known for its burrowing behavior and adaptability to various habitats, including forests, savannas, and agricultural areas. They play an important role in the ecosystem as seed dispersers and contribute to soil aeration through their burrowing activities. However, they are also considered agricultural pests in some regions due to their potential to cause damage to crops.

Overall, the Gambian pouched rat is a fascinating and ecologically significant species within the diverse rodent community of West and Central Africa.
